data.text: Contents
Procedure for the Management of FOI requests ................................................. 9
Introduction

The Freedom of Information Act 2000 (FOIA – “the Act”) underpins the Government's commitment to greater openness in the public sector. The FOIA enables members of the public access to information related to the decisions of public authorities enabling scrutiny and scope for questioning which will ensure that the services provided are efficiently and properly delivered. The Act replaces the non-statutory Code of Practice on Openness in the NHS (1995).

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (the Trust) supports the principle that openness should be the norm in public life and aims to create a climate of openness and dialogue with all stakeholders. Improved access to information about the Trust will facilitate the development of such an environment.

The legislation has a strong presumption that disclosing information held by public authorities is in the public interest and therefore should take place. The Act sets out a range of exemptions that can be applied to justify withholding information that is requested. Whilst some exemptions are “absolute”, most are “qualified”, such that the public authority is required to conduct a “public interest test”, weighing up the general presumption towards disclosure against how the public interest may be better served by withholding information, either temporarily or permanently.

This policy does not overturn the common law duty of confidentiality or statutory provisions that prevent disclosure of personal identifiable information into the public domain. The processing, and exemption rules, related to management and release of such information, is still covered by the subject access provisions of the General Data Protection Regulation (GPDR) and Data Protection Act 2018 (DPA). Aside other statutes covering information access requests, the Trust's Caldicott Guardian will always serve as the Trust's conscience and decision-maker following responsible sharing principles.
Scope

The Trust sets out in this policy its arrangements to ensure compliance with the FOI Act. This document provides a resource for staff to enable awareness of the requirements of the FOIA and the processes the Trust has in place to ensure compliance with the Act.

This policy is intended to cover all business and operational records created in the course of Trust business, i.e. corporate records that are also public records under the terms of the Public Records Act 1958 and 1967.
Where appropriate, this includes email messages and other electronic records.
This policy is aimed at all staff who produce and/or collect and store information as part of the Trust's business.

The policy outlines good practice and identifies the responsibilities of Trust staff. It should be read alongside the documents listed on page 2 under Trust related policies and carried out in accordance with professional codes of conduct.
If the person requesting the information is the subject of the information, they have no right to it under the FOIA, the request becomes a subject access request. For information regarding
Data Subject Access Requests, please refer to Disclosure of Personal Identifiable Data (Subject Access Request) Policy/MSEPO-19024/

If the personal data is about someone other than the applicant, it is handled through the FOI route. There is exemption if disclosure would breach any of the General Data Protection Regulation (GPDR) and Data Protection Act 2018 principles. In these cases, the subject also has the right to object to the disclosure. Subject access requests fall outside the scope of this policy.

The Environmental Information Regulations (EIR) provide general right of access to environmental information, subject to certain exemptions. Requests for environmental information will be processed in the same way as FOI requests.
Definitions

table_items.text: Section 12 of FOIA allows a public authority to refuse to deal with a request where it estimates that it would exceed the appropriate limit to: - either comply with the request in its entirety or; - confirm or deny whether the requested information is held. The estimate must be reasonable in the circumstances of the case. The appropriate limit is currently £600 for central government and £450 for all other public authorities (including the NHS) Where a public authority invokes section 12, it should, where reasonable, provide advice and assistance to help the requestor to refine the request so that it can be dealt with under the appropriate limit.

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000 the Trust has a duty to adopt and maintain a publication scheme. Publication schemes facilitate the proactive release of information and play a crucial role in supporting and providing greater openness and transparency across the public sector.

Senior Information Risk Owner (SIRO) acts as an advocate for information risk on the Board and in internal discussions, and will provide written advice to the Accountable Officer on the content of their Annual Governance Statement (AGS) in regard to information risk.

Information Asset Owner – who in the context of this policy is the person within the directorate or division responsible for collating locally the information required to answer the response and for sending this information to the FOI Manager.

The Information Commissioner's Office is the UK's independent authority set up to uphold information rights in the public interest, promoting openness by public bodies and data privacy for individuals.
The term Caldicott derives from the 1997 report of the Review of Patient- Identifiable Information, chaired by Dame Fiona Caldicott (the Caldicott Report).

This review recommended establishing the role of the Caldicott Guardian to serve as the “conscience” of the organisation in relation to decisions about disclosure and to ensure senior level management of the confidentiality function.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Duties within the Trust (Committees)

The Information Governance Steering Group which is chaired by the SIRO, provides The Trust Management Executive (TMEX) with the assurance that information governance is effectively managed within the organisation. With regard to FOIA it is responsible for:
Receiving quarterly reports on the number of requests received under the FOIA and the numbers responded to within the 20 working day limit;
Receiving details of any requests that have been escalated to the Information Commissioner's Office by the applicant and ensuring appropriate response.
The Trust Management Executive (TMEX)

TMEX is the most senior clinical and operational leadership group within the Trust's governance structure, bringing together senior clinical leaders and the executive team to oversee and make decisions about all aspects of the Trust's operations. TMEX will receive quarterly assurance reports from the Company Secretary setting out at a high level, the Trust's compliance with the response standards detailed below (section 9).

The Audit Committee is the committee of the Trust Board with responsibility for providing assurance to the Board with regard to compliance with the FOIA. The Audit Committee will receive assurance from TMEX, through the Chief Commercial Officer who is executive lead for FOI.
Duties of Individuals within the Trust
The Chief Executive is:

Has ultimate responsibility for the Trust's compliance with the FOIA and should ensure that responsibility for reporting FOI issues is delegated to an appropriate executive to act as the Freedom of Information Lead
The Chief Commercial Officer is:
The Executive portfolio for the FOI policy and for the development and implementation of processes to ensure the trust's compliance with the Act
The point of escalation for complaints about the operation of the FOI function raised by the ICO or other regulators
The point of escalation and decision-making for any proposals to invoke the vexatious applicant procedures
The Chief Information Officer is:
The executive portfolio holder for information governance
The Senior Information Risk Owner (SIRO) and as such has statutory responsibility for all aspects of information governance at a strategic level across the trust.
The Caldicott Guardian – Board appointed Director is responsible for:
Protecting the confidentiality of Personal Identifiable Data (PID) processed by the Trust, ensuring that all sites satisfy the highest practical standards for handling PID.
Acting as the “conscience” of the Trust, by actively supporting work to enable use and sharing of PID where this is appropriate and advising on lawful and ethical solutions.
Championing confidentiality and information sharing requirements and issues at Board level and, where appropriate, at a range of levels within the Trust's overall governance framework.
The Company Secretary is responsible for:
Carrying out internal reviews and responding to queries and complaints over the Trust's service in handling FOI applications in line with the FOI code of practice
Ensuring procedures are in place to systematically review the Trust's arrangements for administering and managing requests for information;

Providing quarterly reports to the IG Steering Group and in turn, TMEX, detailing the trust's performance against the FOI statutory requirements, the Code of Practice and any lessons or themes to be drawn from recent patterns of FOI requests or their responses
Provide details of lessons learnt from internal reviews to colleagues across the trust
Providing support and guidance to the FOI Manager
The FOI Manager is responsible for:
Overseeing implementation of this policy and monitoring its effectiveness
Reviewing and updating this policy and the publication scheme as changes dictate
Managing central collation of information to enable a timely and compliant response within the 20 working day timescale detailed in the Act
Reviewing responses to FOI requests to ensure they provide the relevant information request before response is disclosed
Advising the Company Secretary as necessary concerning applicable exemptions and the rationale for seeking to apply the same
Promoting FOI awareness throughout the Trust by providing training via awareness sessions, and ensuring maintenance of training records
Ensuring the general public has access to information about their rights under the FOI Act
via the Trust's website
Advising staff when requests for information are thought to be exempt under the Act noting for example the distinction between requests for information and surveys
monitoring the contents of the Trust's publication scheme to ensure compliance with the Information Commissioners (ICO) model publication scheme
Advising on the charging requirements where necessary having regard to the current published appropriate limit.
Nominated Departmental and Divisional FOI Leads (Information Asset Owners) are responsible for:
Ensuring that the corporate information kept is of good quality, in terms if accuracy and completeness
Ensuring local procedures are in place to systematically manage the receiving and actioning of requests for information from the FOI Manager
Ensuring all requests for information under the FOIA are dealt with within the deadline given by the FOI Manager
Advising the FIO Manager where information is not available or where there are issues regarding difficulty in providing the information

Ensure the Information required under the Information Commissioners (ICO) publication scheme is published on the hospital website and is updated as and when necessary. To ensure out of date information is removed from the website.
Information not included in the publication scheme is created and stored in accordance with Trust procedures and processes so that it can be found easily when required
All members of staff who produce and/or collect information are responsible for:
Complying with this FOIA policy

Creating/maintaining their own records (paper and electronic) to a standard which adheres to the Trust's records management procedures and processes. This includes retaining email messages, as appropriate.
Informing the FOI Manager of any requests they receive under the FOIA and to forward
them promptly.
General Rights of Access to Information

The FOIA gives general rights of access to recorded information (both paper and electronic) held by the Trust, subject to certain conditions and exemptions. This means that any person who makes a written request has the right to:
Be informed in writing whether the Trust holds the information (this is known as the ‘duty to confirm or deny');
Have access to that information which the Trust holds (subject to any exemptions which may apply).
The Trust need not confirm or deny the existence of information or provide all or part of the information if:
An exemption applies; or
The request is vexatious or similar to a recent previous request; or
The cost of compliance would exceed the ‘appropriate limit' – this is the cost limit as detailed above.
It is a criminal offence to destroy information with intent of preventing disclosure following a request.
Publication Scheme
The Trust is obliged to maintain a publication scheme under the FOIA. A publication scheme is a guide to the information which will routinely be made available to the public by the Trust.

In line with section 20 of the FOIA the Information Commissioner has approved a model publication scheme, on which the Trust's Publication Scheme is based. To assist in the operation of the scheme, and to ensure the Trust publishes in accordance with it, guidance has been produced and is available at https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/guide-to-freedom-of- information/publication-scheme/
The Trust's Publication Scheme details:
The classes of information published, or intended to be published.
The manner in which publication is, or is intended to be made.
Whether the information is available free of charge or if payment is required.

The scheme contains a wide range of information about the Trust that should be routinely made available on the Trust website. This is in addition to information made available to the public in response to Freedom of Information requests. The Publication Scheme will be subject to on-going review in terms of content.
The documents available through the publication scheme will be final approved versions only. It is the Trust's policy not to include draft documents in this scheme.
Procedure for the Management of FOI requests
Appendix 1 shows a flow chart for the FOI process

A request for information must be received in writing stating an address for correspondence, and describe the information requested. For the purposes of general rights of access, a request for information is to be treated as made in writing if it is transmitted by email provided the request is received in legible form and is capable of being used for subsequent reference/reply.
The Trust has established systems and procedures to process applications and monitor the provision of information arising from requests under the Freedom of Information Act.

Detailed knowledge of the FOIA, the exemptions and Trust obligations will be maintained by the FOI Manager and the Company Secretary. The FOI Manager handles the gathering of information to enable a timely response.

All requests made for information under the provisions within the FOIA that might be received by colleagues across the Trust are to be forwarded to the FOI Manager on the day of receipt. These will be recorded on the FOI database so that compliance with the FOI Act can be continually monitored, in terms of response times and the quality of responses provided.

The FOI Manager will send the request for information to the appropriate departmental/division FOI Lead for action, copied to the relevant executive director... The Nominated Departmental and Divisional FOI Leads will coordinate local collation of information and forward to the FOI Manager.
A response will be drafted by the FOI Manager, based on the information provided. The draft will be sent to the relevant executive for approval prior to dispatch.
Statutory Timescales

The legislation stipulates that public authorities must respond to FOI requests within 20 working days of receipt. This “clock” can be stopped and reset in the event that the FOI Manager concludes that the request is insufficiently clear in its content to enable an accurate response to be drafted. Once the applicant provides the necessary clarity, the 20 working day clock starts again at day 1.

Guidance from the ICO suggests that an operational minimum standard of 90% is generally acceptable. However the Trust intends at all times to meet the 20 working day standard in every case and monitors its performance against this standard.

Although the legislation does not stipulate a timescale for issuing an acknowledgement of receipt to FOI applicants, the Code of Practice recommends that a written acknowledgement be provided within 3 working days of receipt. The Trust monitors compliance with this timescale.
Appeals and Complaints
In the first instance, complaints about the Trust's Freedom of Information procedures, and appeals against decisions not to disclose information should be made to the FOI Manager.

If an internal review is required of how the Trust handled the case or there is an appeal against decisions not to disclose information, this will initially be undertaken by the Company Secretary in line with the FOI code of practice.

In all cases, appeals/complaints will be acknowledged promptly and the complainant will be informed of the authority's target date for determining a response. Where it is apparent that determination of the complexity of an appeal/complaint will take longer than the target time, the authority will inform the applicant and explain the reason for the delay. The complainant should always be informed of the outcome of his or her appeal/complaint.
The contact details of the Information Commissioner are as follows:
The Information Commissioner's Office
Wycliffe House
Water Lane
Wilmslow
Cheshire. SK9 5AF
Web Address: https://ico.org.uk/your-data-matters/official-information/
An assessment will be made as to whether or not the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act 2000 have been complied with.
Training

The FOI Manager produced a leaflet called “How to access information about the hospital” to inform service users about how to make requests under the FOIA. This is one of the Trust core leaflets which are available in all public areas.
The FOI Manager produced has informed the Information Asset Owners within Directorates, of:
What the FOIA is and the Trust's responsibilities to meet the Information Commissioners Office requirements
Their role in providing good quality, timely information when requested by the FOI Manager produced
The consequences of not meeting those requirements
The data that needs to be made available to the public in the Publication Scheme on the Trust's website and their responsibilities in keeping it current
Information for all staff regarding FOIA is available on the intranet. Public-facing details of the Trust's policy towards FOIA and how to make a request can be found on the Trust website.
Monitoring Compliance and Reviewing Effectiveness

This document has been approved by the Audit Committee for immediate implementation.
Equality Impact Assessment
This policy has been the subject of an Equality Impact Assessment. The assessment demonstrates that no person or group is disadvantaged as a consequence of this policy (see appendix 3).

Appendix 2 Summary of absolute and qualified exemptions to disclosure under the FOI Act
EXEMPT INFORMATION UNDER PART II OF THE FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT (2000) There are two types of class exemption under the Freedom of Information Act (2000):

applied to information that does not have to be released to the applicant either through the Publication scheme or through the general right of access under the Act. Information to which an absolute exemption applies does not require a public authority to take a test of prejudice nor the balance of public interest to be in favour of non-disclosure. Reference to absolute exemptions can be found in Part I, section 2 and Part II of the Act.

information to which a qualified exemption applies requires a public authority to take a test of prejudice or to demonstrate that the balance of public interest is in favour of non-disclosure. Reference to qualified exemptions can be found in Part I, section 2 and Part II of the Act.

With the exception of section 21 of the Act (information available by other means), exemptions not only apply to the communication of information but also to the duty to confirm or deny, if that itself would disclose information that is reasonable to withhold.
Absolute Exemptions under the Act
Section 21: Information accessible to the applicant by other means
Section 23: Information supplied by, or relating to, bodies dealing with security matters
Section 32: Court Records
Section 34: Parliamentary Privilege
Section 36: Prejudice to effective conduct of public affairs (so far as relating to information held by the House of Commons or the House of Lords)
Section 40: Personal Information (where disclosure may contravene the Data Protection Act 1998)
Section 41: Information provided in confidence
Section 44: Prohibitions on disclosure
Exemptions Qualified by the Public Interest Test
Section 22: Information intended for future publication
Section 24: National Security
Section 26: Defence
Section 27: International Relations
Section 28: Relations within the United Kingdom
Section 29: The Economy
Section 30: Investigations and proceedings conducted by public authorities
Section 31: Law Enforcement
Section 33: Audit Functions
Section 35: Formulation of Government Policy
Section 36: Prejudice to effective conduct of public affairs (for all public authorities except the House of Commons and the House of Lords)
Section 37: Communications with Her Majesty, etc. and honours
Section 38: Health and Safety
Section 39: Environmental Information
Section 42: Legal Professional Privilege
Section 43: Commercial Interests
For further guidance on exemptions under the Act, please visit the Information Commissioners Office website: https://ico.org.uk/

What are you proposing to change?
Policy updated to reflect MSE group role of the FOI function and changes to responsibilities.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Merger of Southend, Basildon & Mid Essex Trusts
Who benefits from this change and how?
Staff will benefit with the simplifying and to streamline of the FOI function across the MSE group
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.

Yes, this has been included as part of the Trust Management Executive (TMEX) meeting
Andrew Stride, Company Secretary & Jonathan Dunk, Chief Commercial Officer
